questions.question_text: Several users with older devices are reporting intermittent connectivity while in an outdoor patio area. After some research, the network administrator determines that an outdoor WAP might help with the issue. However, the company does not want the signal to bleed into the building and cause interference. Which of the following should the network administrator perform to BEST resolve the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Install a directional WAP in the direction of the patio.

Installing a directional WAP is the best solution to provide a strong signal in the patio area without interfering with the building's Wi-Fi signal. Directional WAPs use a focused beam to provide a strong signal in a specific direction, which helps to reduce interference with neighboring Wi-Fi networks. This solution will also ensure that the signal is only available in the patio area, preventing signal bleed into the building.

Selected Answer: C
Option A (disabling the SSID broadcast on the WAP in the patio area) would not necessarily improve connectivity in the patio, and it could make it more difficult for users to connect to the wireless network. Option B (enabling 5GHz only within the patio area) might improve connectivity for devices that support the 5GHz frequency band, but it would not help devices that only support the 2.4GHz frequency band. Option D (installing a repeater on the back wall of the patio area) might help to extend the range of the wireless network, but it would not necessarily improve connectivity for users in the patio.
The more Im thinking about this question the more I realise that it should be C ! :(

choices.A: Disable the SSID broadcast on the WAP in the patio area.
choices.D: Install a repeater on the back wall of the patio area.
choices.C: Install a directional WAP in the direction of the patio.
choices.B: Install a WAP and enable 5GHz only within the patio area.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is most likely to have the HIGHEST latency while being the most accessible?

discussion.content:
A. Satellite

Satellite internet connections typically have higher latency compared to other technologies. This is because the signal must travel to and from satellites in geostationary orbit, resulting in longer round-trip times. While satellite internet can provide coverage in remote or rural areas, it often has higher latency compared to technologies like DSL, cable, or 4G.

Selected Answer: A
Satellite = Method of using communication satellites located in space to connect a user to the Internet (requires satellite. Satellite is best used for mobile users on the go. Speed however is usually slow & service is expensive. There is high latency due to geosynchronous satellites having to communicate around 22,000 miles away from the Earth's surface.

Selected Answer: A
Satellite is most likely to have the HIGHEST latency while being the most accessible. While satellite internet may be available in remote or rural areas where other options like DSL or cable are not available, the signal has to travel long distances to reach the satellite in orbit and then back down to Earth, resulting in high latency.

Selected Answer: A
Answer A is correct !

questions.question_text: Which of the following is used to elect an STP root?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
▪ Root bridge
● Switch elected to act as a reference point for a spanning tree
● Switch with the lowest bridge ID (BID) is elected as the root bridge
● BID is made up of a priority value and a MAC address (with the
lowest value considered root)

-Jason Dion-

Mike Meyers
"Using special STP frames known as bridge protocol data units (BPDUs), switches communicate with other switches to prevent loops from happening in the first place. Configuration BPDUs establish the topology, where one switch is elected root bridge and
acts as the center of the STP universe. Each switch then uses the root bridge as a reference point to maintain a loop-free topology."

Selected Answer: A
The switch with the lowest bridge ID

Selected Answer: A
▪ Root bridge
● Switch elected to act as a reference point for a spanning tree
● Switch with the lowest bridge ID (BID) is elected as the root bridge
● BID is made up of a priority value and a MAC address (with the
lowest value considered root)

Selected Answer: A
From cisco.com:

"As the BPDU goes out through the network, each switch compares the BPDU that the switch sends to the BPDU that the switch receives from the neighbors. The switches then agree on which switch is the root switch. The switch with the lowest ***bridge ID*** in the network wins this election process."

Selected Answer: A
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/spanning-tree-protocol/5234-5.html#:~:text=STP%20calculates%20the%20path%20cost,bridge%20becomes%20the%20root%20port

Right answer is A.
When you learn how to configure stp, you will understand it well. I recommend the CCNA and CCNP Sw completed course.
 When you lhttps://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/spanning-tree-protocol/5234-5.html#:~:text=STP%20calculates%20the%20path%20cost,bridge%20becomes%20the%20root%20port.

Selected Answer: B
In the STP election process a switch port receives superior BPDUs from another switch and identifies that switch as the root bridge. The port with the lowest root path is selected as the root port, if possible.

comments.content: The way I understand it: biggest part of that BPDU is the bridge ID. A BPDU with a lower bridge ID with have a lower value and therefore be considered "superior." Lowest bridge ID should win.
AGAIN you are wrong. All your answers are WRONG!

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Bridge Priority Data Unit (BPDU) – It contains the Bridge ID, Sender’s Bridge ID, Cost to the Root Bridge, Timer values on Root Bridge. All switches exchange BPDU in order to elect root bridge. The switch with the lowest Bridge ID become the root bridge.

Selected Answer: B
This STP information is packaged as bridge 
protocol data unit (BPDU) multicast frames.

Though both the bridge ID and BPDU message are used in the election process I would choose bridge ID since it is closer to the actual election decision. The BPDU message is sent, received, then the bridge ID is extracted, bridge IDs are compared, and finally the election decision is made.
bridge ID

Selected Answer: A
STP elects the root bridge based on the lowest bridge ID, which is a combination of a priority value and a MAC address. The lower the bridge ID, the higher the chance of becoming the root bridge

Selected Answer: A
A, a bridge ID is used to select the STP root

Selected Answer: A
It is A

Selected Answer: B
From Exam Cram:

STP uses bridge protocol data units (BPDUs) to identify the status of ports and
bridges across the network. BPDUs are simple data messages exchanged
between switches. BPDUs contain information on ports and provide the status of
those ports to other switches. If a BPDU message finds a loop in the network, it
is managed by shutting down a particular port or bridge interface.

geeksforgeeks .....
Bridge Priority Data Unit (BPDU) – It contains the Bridge ID, Sender’s Bridge ID, Cost to the Root Bridge, Timer values on Root Bridge. All switches exchange BPDU in order to elect root bridge. The switch with the lowest Bridge ID become the root bridge.
Bridge ID – It is an 8-byte field that is a combination of bridge priority (2 bytes) and Base Mac address (6 bytes) of a device. If there is a tie on bridge priority then the Base Mac address is considered.

Selected Answer: A
BID is an 8-byte value unique to each switch. Switches use BPDU to exchange information with each other, for example the Hello BPDU.
Switches elect a root switch based on the BIDs in the BPDUs. The root switch is the switch
with the lowest numeric value for the BID. So the BID is used to elect the root switch

Selected Answer: A
The STP (Spanning Tree Protocol) root is elected based on the bridge ID (option A).

Selected Answer: B
Mike Meyers says B (:

Selected Answer: A
The root bridge is the bridge with the lowest Bridge ID. All the decisions like which ports are the root ports (the port with the best path to the root bridge) are made from the perspective of the root bridge.

comments.content: The root bridge in Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) is elected based on the lowest bridge ID. The bridge ID is a combination of the bridge priority (a configurable value) and the MAC address of the switch. A lower bridge ID value indicates a higher priority for being elected as the root bridge.
double check yourself before your post
I will go for BridgeId. Although BPDU looks fine as well

questions.question_text: Which of the following commands can be used to display the IP address, subnet address, gateway address, and DNS address on a Windows computer?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The command used to display the IP address, subnet address, gateway address, and DNS address on a Windows computer is:

D. ipconfig /all

The "ipconfig /all" command provides detailed information about the network configuration of the Windows computer, including the IP address, subnet mask, default gateway, and DNS servers.

Selected Answer: D
ipconfig = IP address, Subnet, Gateway, and DNS PREFIX
ipconfig /all = IP address, Subnet, Gateway, AND DNS ADDRESS.

Correct answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
The correct command to display the IP address, subnet address, gateway address, and DNS address on a Windows computer is D. ipconfig /all.

The ipconfig command is a utility that allows you to view and modify the network configuration of a Windows computer. By running the command "ipconfig /all", you can view detailed information about the network configuration of your computer, including the IP address, subnet mask, default gateway, and DNS server addresses.

Option A (netstat -a) is a command that displays active network connections and their status, but it does not display IP address or other network configuration information. Option B (ifconfig) is a command used on Linux and Unix systems to view and modify network configuration, but it is not available on Windows. Option C (ip addr) is a command used on Linux and Unix systems to view and modify network configuration, but it is not available on Windows.

questions.question_text: A user calls the help desk to report being unable to reach a file server. The technician logs in to the user’s computer and verifies that pings fail to respond back when trying to reach the file server. Which of the following would BEST help the technician verify whether the file server is reachable?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Dee.... Deez Nu.......

Selected Answer: D
To verify whether the file server is reachable, the technician can use the traceroute command (option D).

Traceroute is a network diagnostic tool that allows you to trace the path that network packets take from one device to another. By running traceroute to the file server, the technician can see the sequence of devices and networks that the packets pass through on their way to the file server. This can help the technician to determine if there is a problem with the network connection between the user's computer and the file server, or if the issue is with the file server itself.

Selected Answer: D
netstat - to know the status of network
ipconfig - to know ip,subnet,Default gateway and DNS sort of information
nslookup - used to know the DNS information
traceroute - to trace the route, what path data chose to reach

Selected Answer: C
Nslookup

D
Traceroute (or tracert in Windows) is a network diagnostic tool used to trace the route that packets take from one networked device to another. By running a traceroute from the user's computer to the file server, the technician can identify the path the packets are taking and where, if any, communication breakdown occurs. This can help pinpoint where the connection issue might be happening along the network path to the file server.

comments.content: you are over thinking this, use contax cluse, "BEST help the technician verify whether the file server is reachable" real world yes you are correct but for testing no

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The answer should be B.

Traceroute is used when you want to check to route through all the routers. But, in this question it's a fileserver. This is internal traffic and there aren't many routers in an internal network. So, Traceroute is not helpful at all.

With forward chaining troubleshooting, you start with the workstation. In this case, you check it's ip address. If it's an APIPA address, you could have found the issue.
